Name: On-Premises Security Overview
Description: Security posture can be fully customized. Organization controls hardware, data, access, and policies. On-site IT staff handle uptime, patching, and incident response. Ideal for sensitive or regulated data environments.

Name: Decentralized Security Model
Description: Multiple sites, platforms, clouds, and devices. Difficult to secure consistently; configurations may vary. Recommended to move toward centralized visibility and control.

Name: Centralized Security Model
Description: Unified monitoring and policy enforcement. Correlated alerts and consolidated logging. Easier patching and configuration management. Risk: single point of failure—requires redundancy.

Name: Virtual Machines
Description: Run multiple OS instances on shared hardware. Each VM is isolated. Increases efficiency but adds management overhead. Hypervisor security is critical.

Name: Containerization
Description: Runs applications in isolated containers sharing the host OS kernel. Lightweight, portable, and faster than VMs. Applications remain isolated from each other.

Name: Container Images
Description: Portable, reproducible software packages ensuring consistent environments across development and production. Enable scalability and easy deployment.

Name: SCADA / ICS Systems
Description: Used in industrial, manufacturing, and utility environments. Often decades old—must be segmented from IT networks. Critical for energy and automation control.

Name: RTOS (Real-Time Operating System)
Description: Executes tasks at precise intervals for avionics, medical, or automotive use. Prioritizes reliability over new features; limited built-in security.

Name: Embedded Systems
Description: Hardware + software built for a specific purpose such as IoT, wearables, or medical devices. Usually difficult to update or patch securely.

Name: High Availability (HA)
Description: Multiple systems work together to prevent downtime. Requires configuration, monitoring, and testing. Adds cost and complexity but increases uptime.

Name: MTTR (Mean Time to Repair)
Description: Average time required to restore service after failure. Lower MTTR = faster recovery and better availability.

Name: Network Device Placement
Description: Firewalls separate trusted and untrusted zones. Jump servers mediate admin access. Honeypots lure attackers for analysis.

Name: Security Zones
Description: Logical network divisions—trusted, internal, DMZ, external—simplify firewall rules and access controls.

Name: Attack Surface Reduction
Description: Minimize exposed services, ports, code, and privileges. Perform continuous auditing, hardening, and monitoring.

Name: Connectivity Security
Description: Protect physical cabling and network ports. Use encryption such as IPsec, TLS, and VPN tunnels.

Name: Fail-Open vs Fail-Closed
Description: Fail-Open: traffic continues if system fails—higher availability, lower security. Fail-Closed: traffic stops—higher security, lower availability.

Name: Active Monitoring (Inline)
Description: Traffic flows through the security device for real-time blocking (e.g., IPS). Risk: device failure may interrupt traffic.

Name: Passive Monitoring (Out-of-Band)
Description: Traffic is mirrored to tools like IDS. Detects but cannot block threats—adds visibility without disrupting flow.

Name: Jump Servers
Description: Hardened gateways providing controlled administrative access to secure internal networks. If compromised, impact is severe.

Name: Proxy Servers
Description: Intermediate systems that provide caching, filtering, and inspection. Forward proxies control outbound user access; reverse proxies protect internal servers.

Name: Open Proxies
Description: Public proxies with no authentication or control—significant security risk allowing anonymous misuse.

Name: Load Balancing (Active/Active)
Description: Distributes traffic across multiple active servers for better performance and redundancy.

Name: Load Balancing (Active/Passive)
Description: Secondary server remains idle until primary fails. Easier to implement but less resource-efficient.

Name: Logging and Monitoring Tools
Description: Sensors collect firewall, server, and auth logs. Collectors (SIEM/syslog) aggregate and correlate data for threat detection.

Name: Port Security and Network Access Control (NAC)
Description: 802.1X + EAP require device authentication before access. Uses RADIUS, LDAP, TACACS+, or Kerberos. Client = Supplicant; Switch/AP = Authenticator; Server = Auth Authority.

Name: Traditional Firewall / UTM
Description: Filters traffic by port, protocol, and IP. May include VPN, spam filtering, IDS/IPS, and bandwidth control.

Name: Next-Gen Firewall (NGFW)
Description: Performs deep packet inspection to identify apps and content. Filters based on behavior, not just ports.

Name: WAF (Web Application Firewall)
Description: Protects web apps from SQLi, XSS, and HTTP(S) exploits. Common in PCI DSS compliance environments.

Name: VPN Technologies
Description: Encrypt data across public networks. VPN concentrators handle authentication and encryption.

Name: SSL/TLS VPN
Description: Users connect via browser or lightweight client over TCP 443, which bypasses most firewall restrictions.

Name: Site-to-Site IPsec VPN
Description: Always-on secure tunnel between networks for continuous encrypted connectivity.

Name: SD-WAN and SASE
Description: SD-WAN routes cloud traffic efficiently. SASE provides cloud-based security edge for remote users.

Name: Data Types
Description: Includes proprietary data, PII, PHI, and legal/financial records. Must be protected according to classification and regulation.

Name: Data Classification Levels
Description: Public, Sensitive/Internal, Private/Confidential, and Critical. Determines handling and protection requirements.

Name: Data States
Description: Data at Rest → encrypt + access control. Data in Transit → protect with TLS/IPsec. Data in Use → vulnerable in memory—use hardware protections.

Name: Data Sovereignty
Description: Data is governed by laws of its storage region (e.g., GDPR). Organizations must respect local compliance requirements.

Name: Data Protection Techniques
Description: Encryption, hashing, obfuscation, masking, tokenization, segmentation, and access permissions ensure confidentiality and integrity.

Name: High Availability and Business Continuity
Description: Server clustering, load balancing, and site resiliency keep operations running during failures.

Name: Backup Strategies
Description: Use on-site/off-site backups, snapshots, replication, and journaling for data recovery.

Name: Disaster Recovery Testing
Description: Conduct tabletop exercises, simulations, and failover tests to validate plans and reduce MTTR.

Name: Power Resilience
Description: UPS provides short-term backup; generators ensure long-term continuity during outages.
